p: Curcumin is a yellow pigment present in turmeric, a spice widely used throughout the world, and in traditional Asian and African medicine to treat a wide range of illnesses for over 4000 years. It has been shown to exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-microbial, and anti-carcinogenic effects [ 94, 116]. Moreover, the safety, tolerability, and non-toxicity of curcumin at high doses are well established in various human and animal models [ 116, 117, 118, 119]. Besides being able to inhibit DENV, JEV, ZIKV, and CHIKV [ 97, 98, 99], curcumin has been reported to exhibit broad-spectrum antiviral activity against several enveloped viruses including PR8 influenza virus, vaccinia virus, pseudorabies virus, Newcastle disease virus [ 98], HCV [ 120], and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) [ 121]. In contrast, the non-enveloped enterovirus-A71 (EV-A71) remained unaffected by curcumin treatment [ 98]. In general, the specific mechanisms by which curcumin exerts its antiviral effects against arboviruses is not well understood (refer to Table 2), but it has been proposed that the compound inhibits virus attachment to host cells [ 99].
